title: Hack's Impairment Index (HII)
description: Provides a quantitative and standardized assessment of the degree of alcohol-induced impairment in emergency department patients. Creates an objective, serializable evaluation of clinical intoxication.

ranges.description: Minimal to no clinically significant impairment
ranges.interpretation: Patient shows minimal signs of alcohol-induced impairment. Consider evaluation for discharge if other clinical criteria are met.
Patient shows mild impairment. Continue monitoring and reassess in 2 hours. Consider evaluation for potential alcohol withdrawal.
Patient shows moderate impairment. Not safe for discharge. Continue supportive care and reassess every 2 hours.
Patient shows severe impairment. Requires close monitoring and supportive care. Reassess frequently.
Patient shows profound impairment. May require intensive monitoring and airway protection. Consider ICU level care.

references: Hack JB, Goldlust EJ, Gibbs F, Zink B. The H-Impairment Index (HII): a standardized assessment of alcohol-induced impairment in the Emergency Department. Am J Drug Alcohol Abuse. 2014 Mar;40(2):111-7. doi: 10.3109/00952990.2013.877019.
Hack JB, Hoffman RS. Thiamine before glucose to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy: examining the conventional wisdom. JAMA. 1998 Feb 25;279(8):583-4. doi: 10.1001/jama.279.8.583.

Goldlust EJ, Bookstaver AD, Zink BJ, Hack JB. Performance of the Hack's Impairment Index Score: A Novel Tool to Assess Impairment from Alcohol in Emergency Department Patients. Acad Emerg Med. 2017 Oct;24(10):1193-1203. doi: 10.1111/acem.13256.
formula: HII Score = (Sum of all subscores) / (Number of tasks completed Ã— 4)
notes: Each task is scored from 0 (normal/baseline) to 4 (unable to participate)
Serial assessments should be performed every 2 hours
Estimated time to resolution (hours) = HII Score / 0.0616
HII <4 generally indicates readiness for clinical discharge evaluation
Not intended to determine driving safety or replace clinical judgment
Superior to blood alcohol levels for assessing clinical impairment
